The function $f(x)$ satisfies
\[f(x) + f(x + 2y) = 6x + 6y - 8\]for all real numbers $x$ and $y.$  Find the value of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0.$
inference:
Setting $x = y = 0,$ we get
\[f(0) + f(0) = -8,\]so $f(0) = -4.$

Setting $y = -x,$ we get
\[f(x) + f(-x) = -8\]for all real numbers $x.$  Hence, $f(-x) = -8 - f(x).$

Setting $y = x,$ we get
\[f(x) + f(3x) = 6x + 6x - 8 = 12x - 8.\]Then
\[f(3x) = 12x - 8 - f(x).\]Setting $x = \frac{x}{3},$ we get
\[f(x) = 4x - 8 - f \left( \frac{x}{3} \right).\]Then
\[f \left( \frac{x}{3} \right) = 4x - 8 - f(x).\]Hence,
\[f(3x) = 12x - 8 - f(x) = 12x - 8 - (4x - 8 - f \left( \frac{x}{3} \right)) = 8x + f \left( \frac{x}{3} \right).\]Then
\[f(3x) - f \left( \frac{x}{3} \right) = 8x.\]Setting $x = \frac{x}{3},$ we get
\[f(x) - f \left( \frac{x}{9} \right) = \frac{8}{3} x.\]Then
\[f(x) = f \left( \frac{x}{9} \right) + \frac{8}{3} x.\]Setting $x = \frac{x}{9},$ we get
\[f \left( \frac{x}{9} \right) = f \left( \frac{x}{81} \right) + \frac{8}{27} x.\]Then
\[f(x) = f \left( \frac{x}{81} \right) + \frac{8}{27} x + \frac{8}{3} x = f \left( \frac{x}{81} \right) + \frac{80}{27} x.\]Continuing in this way, we get
\[f(x) = f \left( \frac{x}{9^n} \right) + \frac{80}{27} x \left( 1 + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{9^2} + \dots + \frac{1}{9^{n - 1}} \right)\]for all positive integers $n.$  The geometric series converges to $\frac{9}{8},$ so
\[f(x) = f \left( \frac{x}{9^n} \right) + 10x\]for all positive integers $n.$

As $n$ approaches infinity, $\frac{x}{9^n}$ approaches 0, so
\[f(x) = f(0) + 10x = -4 + 10x.\]Setting $f(x) = 0,$ we get $-4 + 10x = 0,$ so $x = \boxed{\frac{2}{5}}.$
